entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 17 at 4:04PM CDT until August 17 at 4:15PM CDT by NWS Huntsville AL
entry.summary:

SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
Locations impacted include... Fort Payne, Henagar, Sylvania, Valley Head, Hammondville, Mentone, and Desoto State Park.

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 17 at 5:01PM EDT until August 17 at 5:15PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
At 500 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Nanjemoy Creek, moving east at 20 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Damaging winds will cause some trees and large branches to fall. This could injure those outdoors, as well as damage homes and vehicles. Roadways may become blocked by downed trees. Localized power outages are possible. Unsecured light objects may become projectiles.
Locations impacted include... King George, Dahlgren, Fairview Beach, Nanjemoy Creek, Port Tobacco River, Popes Creek, Tompkinsville, Weedonville, Newburg, Nanjemoy, Swan Point, Welcome, Berthaville, and Ninde.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 17 at 4:01PM CDT until August 17 at 6:00PM CDT by NWS New Orleans LA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of southeast Louisiana, including the following parishes, Jefferson, Orleans and Plaquemines.
* WHEN...Until 600 PM CDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 401 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 0.5 and 1 inch of rain has fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 1.5 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... New Orleans, Harvey, Marrero, Timberlane, Belle Chasse, Gretna, Westwego, Woodmere, Estelle and Terrytown. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Jefferson, LA; Orleans, LA; Plaquemines, LA

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM CDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 17 at 3:30PM CDT by NWS Duluth MN
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency has issued an Air Quality Alert for fine particles pollution. The Air Quality Index (AQI) is expected to reach the Orange or Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups category.
* WHERE...North central and northeastern Minnesota.
* WHEN...Until noon CDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Sensitive groups, such as people with lung disease (including asthma), heart disease, and children and older adults, may experience health effects.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heavy ground-level smoke is expected to move into northwest Minnesota Friday evening.. Northerly winds behind a strong low pressure system will pull smoke south across the northern half of Minnesota through Monday morning. Smoke will produce air quality in Orange (Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups) category intermittently from Friday evening through noon on Monday. The air quality may temporarily improve during the afternoon hours before degrading again overnight. Areas near Lake Superior may also experience smoke trapped in marine fog, similar to what occured earlier this week. Because of this air quality may be worse immediately surrounding Lake Superior compared to areas inland.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Koochiching; North St. Louis; Northern Cook/Northern Lake; North Itasca; Central St. Louis; Southern Lake/North Shore; Southern Cook/North Shore; North Cass; South Itasca; Northern Aitkin; Carlton/South St. Louis

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 17 at 3:37PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
entry.summary:
AQAHGX
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an Ozone Action Day for the Houston, Galveston, and Brazoria area for Sunday, August 18, 2024
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone pollution in the Houston, Galveston, and surrounding areas on Sunday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive through lanes, conserving energy and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
For more information on ozone:
Ozone: The Facts www.tceq.texas.gov/airquality/monops/ozonefacts.html EPA AirNow: www.airnow.gov/?city=Houston&state=TX&country=USA Take Care of Texas: www.takecareoftexas.org/conservation-tips/keep-our-air-clean

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 17 at 4:33PM EDT by NWS Buffalo NY
entry.summary:
At 433 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near Wattsburg, or 21 miles southeast of Erie, moving east at 35 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and half inch hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.
Locations impacted include... Jamestown, Clymer, Jamestown West, Frewsburg, Busti, French Creek, Panama, Niobe, and Ashville.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Chautauqua

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 17 at 1:21PM MST until August 17 at 2:45PM MST by NWS Flagstaff AZ
entry.summary:
At 120 PM MST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms produced heavy rain across portions of House Rock Rd near the Arizona and Utah border. Between 0.75 and 1.5 inches of rain have fallen. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly, with the runoff traveling northward through Coyote Wash and into Buckskin Wash.
HAZARD...Life-threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Life-threatening flash flooding of low-water crossings, creeks, normally dry washes and roads.
Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... The Wave and Vermilion Cliffs National Monument.
This includes the following creeks, washes and rivers... Rock Canyon, Coyote Wash and White Sage Wash.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coconino, AZ

cap:parameter.value: FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 245 PM MST THIS AFTERNOON FOR COCONINO COUNTY

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 17 at 1:19PM MST until August 17 at 9:15PM MST by NWS Flagstaff AZ
entry.summary:
FFWFGZ
The National Weather Service in Flagstaff has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... The Paria River in... Coconino County in north central Arizona...
* Until 915 PM MST /1015 PM MDT/ Saturday.
* At 113 PM MST /213 PM MDT/, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain over the Paria River drainage in Utah. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly through the Paria River.
HAZARD...Life-threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding in and around the Paria River.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of areas in and around the Paria River.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Paria Canyon, Paria River Slot Canyon, Glen Canyon National Recreation Area, Grand Canyon National Park, Vermilion Cliffs National Monument and Lees Ferry.
This includes the following recreation areas and campgrounds... Lee's Ferry Campground, Lees Ferry Campground and Lees Ferry Camp Site.
This includes the following slot canyons... Paria River upstream of Lees Ferry.
This includes the following creeks, washes and rivers... Paria River and Colorado River.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coconino, AZ

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 17 at 3:18PM EDT until August 17 at 6:30PM EDT by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Portions of northeast Ohio, including the following county, Ashtabula and northwest Pennsylvania, including the following county, Erie.
* WHEN...Until 630 PM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 318 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Conneaut, Girard, North Kingsville, Albion, Lake City, Cranesville, Platea, McKean, Avonia and Kelloggsville. - Please visit www.weather.gov/safety/flood for flood safety and preparedness information
entry.cap:areaDesc: Ashtabula, OH; Erie, PA

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued August 17 at 11:01AM AKDT until August 19 at 4:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 4 to 6 feet. Elevated water levels of 4 to 6 feet above the normal high tideline, highest over Eastern Norton Sound. Water levels of 2 to 4 feet are expected over the south facing coast of Western Norton Sound.
* WHERE...Southern Seward Peninsula Coast and Eastern Norton Sound.
* WHEN...From 4 AM Sunday to 4 PM AKDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Localized beach erosion may occur. Items along the beach may wash away.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...South winds to 20 to 35 mph Sunday morning will turn to southwest winds 20 to 25 mph Sunday evening, then westerly 25 to 35 mph Sunday night and Monday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 4 AM SUNDAY TO 4 PM AKDT MONDAY

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued August 17 at 11:01AM AKDT until August 19 at 4:00PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 3 to 5 feet, with 4 to 7 feet along the Chukchi coast.
* WHERE...Baldwin Peninsula, Northern Seward Peninsula and Shishmaref.
* WHEN...From 4 AM Sunday to 4 PM AKDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Localized beach erosion may occur. Items along the beach may wash away.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...West to northwest winds of 25 to 35 mph will move across the Chukchi Coast and into Kotzebue Sound Sunday late afternoon along the Chukchi Coast, and Sunday evening across Kotzebue Sound. The highest winds and seas are diminishing Monday morning. Water levels are expected to be 2 to 3 feet above the normal high tideline during the peak of the event.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 17 at 11:46AM MST until August 17 at 9:00PM MST by NWS Flagstaff AZ
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Potential for Flash flooding, caused by excessive rainfall over portions of central, western and northern Coconino County.
* WHERE...A portion of north central Arizona, including the following areas, Coconino Plateau, Grand Canyon Country, Kaibab Plateau and Marble and Glen Canyons.
* WHEN...Until 9 PM MST /10 PM MDT/ this evening.
* IMPACTS...Flash flooding will be possible in the Paria River, many normally dry washes, swimming holes and over burned areas such as the Mangum Fire Scar. Raging killer currents will be possible in side canyons and narrow slot canyons including Waterholes Canyon and Antelope Canyon. This Watch includes the Grand Canyon and Supai.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Monsoon moisture will rapidly increase across the area, raising the potential for flash flooding due to heavy rainfall from thunderstorms. Storms are already firing up across the area as of 11:45 AM MST. - Visit www.weather.gov/safety/flood for more information on flood safety.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kaibab Plateau; Marble and Glen Canyons; Grand Canyon Country; Coconino Plateau

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued August 17 at 10:05AM PDT until August 18 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Las Vegas NV
entry.summary:
Southerly to southwesterly winds will increase today as a trough digs along the West Coast. These winds combined with afternoon relative humidities around 10% to 15% and dry fuels will result in critical fire weather conditions across Esmeralda and Nye Counties in southern Nevada. Winds will drop off and relative humidities will recover tonight into Sunday morning before critical conditions return Sunday afternoon.
* AFFECTED AREA...In Nevada...Fire weather zones 460 and 462.
* TIMING...1100 AM PDT today through 800 PM PDT Sunday.
* WIND...15 to 25 mph southerly winds with gusts around 35 mph.
* HUMIDITY...10 to 15 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Esmeralda and Nye County Deserts/CNC Dispatch; Nye County Deserts/Las Vegas Dispatch

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 17 at 12:17PM EDT until August 18 at 1:30PM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Madison County Emergency Management continues to report gradually rising water levels in southeastern Madison County between State Road 53 and the Suwannee River. Water levels remain high in the vicinity of I-10 and Exit 258 and 262. All of the flooding is due to past heavy rainfall from Hurricane Debby. Expect new flooded areas as water continues to slowly move to the south and east across Madison County.
* WHERE...A portion of Big Bend Florida, including the following county, Madison.
* WHEN...Until 130 PM EDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is occurring. Numerous roads remain closed due to flooding. Expect many areas of slow moving or standing water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1210 PM EDT, Madison County Emergency Management reports continued flooding in the warned area. - Flooding will likely persist into next week due to more than 12 inches of rain that occurred across the warning area from Hurricane Debby around August 5. With high groundwater levels, locations near small creeks, springs, or sinks in Southeast Madison County could be prone to flooding on relatively short notice. If you live in an area prone to flooding, take action to protect property. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Lee and Hopewell. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Madison, FL

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 17 at 9:16AM CDT by NWS Omaha/Valley NE
entry.summary:
The following is transmitted in collaboration with the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services and the Nebraska Department of Environment and Energy...
WHAT...Air Quality Alert
WHERE...Northern Nebraska and portions of central Nebraska
WHEN...08/16/2024 5:00 PM until 08/18/2024 3:00 AM
POLLUTANT...PM 2.5 particulates
AIR QUALITY INDEX...Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups to Unhealthy
ADDITIONAL DETAILS...An alert for possible, periodic exposure to Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups (Air Quality Index orange category) to Unhealthy (Air Quality Index red category) air quality due to smoke has been issued for the following Nebraska counties - Sioux, Dawes, Box Butte, Sheridan, Garden, Cherry, Grant, Arthur, Keith, Hooker, McPherson, Lincoln, Thomas, Logan, Keya Paha, Brown, Rock, Blaine, Loup, Custer, Boyd, Holt, Garfield, Wheeler, Knox, Antelope, Boone, Cedar, Pierce, Madison, Dixon, Dakota, Wayne, Stanton, Thurston, Cuming, Burt, Dodge, and Washington from Friday, August 16 th , at 5PM to Sunday, August 18 th , at 3 AM.
During Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups (AQI orange category) conditions, members of sensitive groups may experience health effects. Sensitive groups include people with heart or lung disease, older adults, and children. When conditions rise to the orange category, sensitive groups are advised to reduce prolonged or heavy exertion and avoid intense outdoor activities. During Unhealthy AQI (Red category) conditions, some members of the general public may experience health effects and members of sensitive groups may experience more serious health effects. Sensitive groups include people with heart or lung disease, older adults, and children. When conditions rise to the red category, everyone is advised to avoid prolonged or heavy exertion and those in sensitive groups should consider moving activities indoors or rescheduling.
Smoke from Canadian and western U.S. wildfires may affect the air quality in Nebraska. Smoke levels and wind directions are monitored by Nebraska and other states to predict when impacts to the air quality may occur. Information regarding wildfires and Impacts in Nebraska is available from the Nebraska Department of Environment and Energy (NDEE) at http://dee.ne.gov/NDEQProg.nsf/OnWeb/AirSA-3 Alerts are based on data available from weather forecasts, smoke plume modeling, satellite imagery, and from air quality monitors located in Omaha, Bellevue, Blair, Lincoln, Beatrice, Grand Island, and Scottsbluff.
Advisories for smoke and air quality are issued for affected areas by the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) and Department of Environment and Energy (NDEE) and posted on agency webpages and social media sites. By notifying the media and local health departments, alerts help citizens protect their health by informing them of days where outdoor activities should be reduced or avoided to minimize exposure to smoke.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Knox; Cedar; Thurston; Antelope; Pierce; Wayne; Boone; Madison; Stanton; Cuming; Burt; Dodge; Washington

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued August 17 at 9:48AM EDT until August 18 at 12:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...One to two feet of inundation above ground level expected in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways.
* WHERE...The lower Cape Fear River including downtown Wilmington.
* WHEN...From 6 PM this evening to midnight EDT tonight.
* IMPACTS...Portions of Battleship Road and USS North Carolina Road may become impassable. In downtown Wilmington, flooding expands on Water Street from Orange Street to Red Cross Street. The lowest portions of Water Street between Princess and Orange Streets may become impassable. Flooding worsens on the lowest spots of River Road and adjacent residential roads, south of River Road Park. Route 133 at Little Mallory Creek may be flooded. Highway 421 Truck near Carolina Beach Road begins to flood. Check with local officials for any road closures or impacts.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Affected areas listed are based on average tide conditions. Additional locations may experience flooding during periods of heavy rainfall, high winds, or other factors.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued August 17 at 3:07AM HST until August 19 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...MINOR COASTAL FLOODING DURING AFTERNOON HIGH TIDES THROUGH MONDAY...
.The combination of the upcoming full moon and water levels running around 0.5 ft higher than predicted levels could produce minor coastal flooding through Monday afternoon during the times of the afternoon high tide.
* WHAT...Isolated minor coastal flooding.
* WHERE...Along shorelines and low-lying coastal areas of all islands.
* WHEN...During the afternoon high tide each afternoon through Monday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of beaches that are normally dry, minor coastal erosion, and saltwater inundation.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued August 17 at 3:56AM AKDT until August 18 at 6:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* LOCATION...Along the Kuskokwim Delta coast, especially the communities of Kongiganak, Kwigillingok, and Kipnuk.
* COASTAL FLOODING...Water levels will rise as high as 3 to 6 feet above normal highest tide. While water levels will drop during low tide, expect higher than usual water levels to return during high tide.
* TIMING...Through 6 PM Sunday, as several rounds of strong winds impact the Kuskokwim Delta coast. The timing of highest water levels will depend on tide cycles at your location. Generally, the strongest winds are expected: (1) Through later this morning; and (2) early Sunday morning through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding of low lying areas along the coast. Strong winds, high surf, and wave run-up could move property along the shoreline. Coastal erosion is possible. Strong, sustained winds could slow the retreat of water during low tide.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...There is now increased confidence for the most significant higher water, waves and strong winds to occur around midday Sunday. Winds and higher than normal water levels will slowly diminish by Sunday night.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kuskokwim Delta

This includes the Warner Peak Fire, Adel, Paisley and the Hart Mountain Refuge. In California, the eastern half of Fire Weather Zone 285, including Alturas.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued August 17 at 4:19AM PDT until August 17 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* IMPACTS...Abundant lightning on dry fuels could lead to numerous new fire starts. Gusty, shifting outflow winds could also result in changing fire behavior and spread. These winds could also present a danger to aircraft and ground personnel.
* AFFECTED AREA...In California...Fire weather zones 280 and 281. In Oregon...Fire weather zones 616, 617, 620, 621, 622 and 623.
* THUNDERSTORMS...Scattered to numerous thunderstorms are expected to develop this afternoon and move from south to north through the area into the evening. These storms will contain frequent and abundant cloud to ground lightning. Some of the stronger thunderstorms may contain strong to severe wind gusts and hail. Rainfall is expected with these storms and could be heavy at times.
* OUTFLOW WINDS...Gusts up to 60 mph.
* HAIL POTENTIAL...5 to 15 percent chance of one half to 1 inch diameter hail.
* DETAILED URL...View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr

entry.title: Flash Flood Watch issued August 17 at 3:59AM PDT until August 18 at 2:00AM PDT by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding and debris flows caused by excessive rainfall continue to be possible. The greatest concern remains over the 2024 burn areas associated with active wildfires, but there is also a small probability that rainfall rates could approach threshold values over burn areas from previous years.
* WHERE...Portions of Oregon, including the following areas, Cascades of Lane County, Cascades of Marion and Linn Counties and North Oregon Cascades and southwest Washington, including the following area, South Washington Cascades.
* WHEN...From 2 PM PDT this afternoon through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Heavy rainfall over Cascade burn areas during the period of the watch. Residents near the 2024 burn areas associated with active wildfires should prepare for potential flooding impacts. Be sure to stay up to date with information from local authorities. Heavy rainfall could trigger flash flooding of low-lying areas, urbanized street flooding, and debris flows in and near recent wildfire burn scars.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - National Weather Service Meteorologists are forecasting heavy rainfall, which may lead to flash flooding and debris flows over recent burn areas in the Cascades. Hourly rainfall rates up to 0.75 inches per hour will be possible. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 17 at 2:53AM AKDT until August 18 at 6:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by high winds and storm surge backing up the Kuskokwim River is expected.
* WHERE...The Lower Kuskokwim River, primarily south of Tuluksak down to the mouth of the river.
* WHEN...Until 600 PM AKDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas along the Kuskokwim River as well as nearby waterways which feed into the Kuskokwim River.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 224 AM AKDT, river gauge reports indicate water levels are falling as water from recent rainfall exits the Kuskokwim River into the Kuskokwim Bay along with the approach of low tide. However, persistent strong south to southwest winds and associated storm surge will help back up water in the Kuskokwim River and combine with astronomical high tides to produce high water levels and minor flooding along the lower Kuskokwim River the next two days.
Water levels at high tide this afternoon will likely be a little higher than high tide on Friday afternoon. A stronger push of winds (up to 60 mph gusts) and storm surge on Sunday will then lead to the highest water levels Sunday afternoon, which is the most likely time to see flooding in communities along the lower Kuskokwim River.
- In Bethel, minor flooding in the Brown Slough and other low lying areas is likely.
For other villages along the lower Kuskokwim River, flooding of low lying areas is likely.
For the Tundra Villages of Kasigluk, Nunapitchuk and Atmautluk, there is the possibility that winds could push water levels higher and boardwalks and low lying areas could become flooded.
If you live near or along the Lower Kuskokwim River, stay alert and be prepared to take action.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kuskokwim Delta

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued August 17 at 2:27AM PDT until August 17 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Pendleton OR
entry.summary:
...STRONG TO SEVERE THUNDERSTORMS WILL IMPACT THE CASCADE MOUNTAINS TODAY, EXTENDING TO THE EASTERN SLOPES, WHILE SOUTHEASTERN OREGON SEES DRY, WINDY, AND UNSTABLE CONDITIONS...
.A potent weather system will bring a myriad of impacts to the forecast area today. For the Cascade Mountains and east slopes, strong to severe thunderstorms will trek across primarily the spine of the Cascades starting in the afternoon down around central Oregon, advancing northward into the Washington Cascades by the evening. While storms along the Cascades are expected to be accompanied by a significant wetting rain, isolated to scattered storms extending into the east slopes and portions of the Columbia Basin will be much drier, leading to critical fire weather conditions due to abundant lightning with a lack of wetting rain.
For southeastern Oregon, this same weather system will usher in hot and dry desert air, leading to breezy winds combined with low RHs and locally unstable conditions. Showers and storms are not anticipated to track as far east as southeastern Oregon.
Users should note that OR641 and WA691 are under partial Red Flag Warnings. The Warned zones include only the western half of each zone, and not the entirety of the zone.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 642 Southern Blue and Strawberry Mountains.
* WINDS...South 10 to 20 mph with gusts up to 30 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 10 percent.
* IMPACTS...Gusty winds with dry conditions may lead to rapid fire spread. Unstable conditions may promote extreme fire behavior as well.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Blue and Strawberry Mountains

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 17 at 3:17AM CDT by NWS Brownsville TX
entry.summary:
The combination of above normal high temperatures and relative humidity percentages will result in uncomfortably hot conditions across Deep South Texas and the Rio Grande Valley today. Heat index values are expected to range between 105 and 110 degrees this afternoon and early evening. Isolated areas may briefly experience heat indices up to 111 degrees for a short period of time.
If working outside today, be sure to drink plenty of water, wear loose-fitting and light-colored clothing, and take frequent breaks in air-conditioned locations. Be sure to check on elderly and infirm neighbors and relatives, provide shade and fresh water for outdoor pets and livestock, and check the backseat of your vehicle when transporting children.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 16 at 4:10PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment has issued the following...
WHAT...Ozone Action Day Alert.
WHERE...Douglas, Jefferson, Denver, western Arapahoe, western Adams, Broomfield, Boulder, Larimer, and Weld Counties
WHEN...400 PM Friday August 16 to 400 PM Saturday August 17
IMPACTS...Ozone Action Day Alert is now in effect for the Front Range Urban Corridor. Request to limit driving gas and diesel- powered vehicles is now in effect until at least 4 p.m. Saturday, August 17, 2024. Hot and stagnant weather will allow ozone to reach the Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups Category on Friday and Saturday.For areas included in this advisory that are not expected to reach the Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups (USG) air quality designation, we request that activities, such as driving non-ZEV vehicles (i.e., gas or diesel), be reduced to lessen the impacts on neighboring air quality. Additional air pollution in this region may directly worsen air quality or contribute to precursors which may also adversely affect air quality. For Colorado air quality conditions, forecasts and advisories, visit: https://www.colorado.gov/airquality/colorado_summary.aspx
HEALTH INFORMATION...Increasing likelihood of respiratory symptoms and breathing discomfort in active children and adults and people with lung disease, such as asthma. Active children and adults, and people with lung disease, such as asthma, should reduce prolonged or heavy outdoor exertion.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Boulder, CO; Weld, CO; Adams, CO; Denver, CO; Jefferson, CO; Douglas, CO; Arapahoe, CO; Broomfield, CO; Larimer, CO

This includes the cities of Nome, White Mountain, Golovin, Serpentine Hot Springs, Council, Haycock, Pilgrim Springs, And Taylor.

Additionally, heavy rain could potentially impact crossings on the road to Council and the road to Teller.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 16 at 4:21PM CDT by NWS Sioux Falls SD
entry.summary:
The following is transmitted in collaboration with the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services and the Nebraska Department of Environment and Energy...
WHAT...Air Quality Alert
WHERE...Northern Nebraska and portions of central Nebraska
WHEN...8/16/2024 5:00 PM to 8/18/2024 3:00 AM
POLLUTANT...PM 2.5 particulates
AIR QUALITY INDEX...Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups to Unhealthy
ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
An alert for possible, periodic exposure to Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups (Air Quality Index orange category) to Unhealthy (Air Quality Index red category) air quality due to smoke has been issued for the following Nebraska counties - Sioux, Dawes, Box Butte, Sheridan, Garden, Cherry, Grant, Arthur, Keith, Hooker, McPherson, Lincoln, Thomas, Logan, Keya Paha, Brown, Rock, Blaine, Loup, Custer, Boyd, Holt, Garfield, Wheeler, Knox, Antelope, Boone, Cedar, Pierce, Madison, Dixon, Dakota, Wayne, Stanton, Thurston, Cuming, Burt, Dodge, and Washington from Friday, August 16th, at 5:00 PM to Sunday, August 18th, at 3:00 AM.
During Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups AQI (orange category) conditions, members of sensitive groups may experience health effects. Sensitive groups include people with heart or lung disease, older adults, and children. When conditions rise to the orange category, sensitive groups are advised to reduce prolonged or heavy exertion and avoid intense outdoor activities.
During Unhealthy AQI (Red category) conditions, some members of the general public may experience health effects and members of sensitive groups may experience more serious health effects. Sensitive groups include people with heart or lung disease, older adults, and children. When conditions rise to the red category, everyone is advised to avoid prolonged or heavy exertion and those in sensitive groups should consider moving activities indoors or rescheduling.
Smoke from Canadian and western U.S. wildfires may affect the air quality in Nebraska. Smoke levels and wind directions are monitored by Nebraska and other states to predict when impacts to the air quality may occur.
Information regarding wildfires and Impacts in Nebraska is available from the Nebraska Department of Environment and Energy (NDEE) at http://dee.ne.gov/NDEQProg.nsf/OnWeb/AirSA-3
Alerts are based on data available from weather forecasts, smoke plume modeling, satellite imagery, and from air quality monitors located in Omaha, Bellevue, Blair, Lincoln, Beatrice, Grand Island, and Scottsbluff.
Advisories for smoke and air quality are issued for affected areas by the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) and Department of Environment and Energy (NDEE) and posted on agency webpages and social media sites. By notifying the media and local health departments, alerts help citizens protect their health by informing them of days where outdoor activities should be reduced or avoided to minimize exposure to smoke.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Dixon; Dakota

* IMPACTS...Sensitive groups, such as people with lung disease (including asthma), heart disease, and children and older adults, may experience health effects.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heavy ground-level smoke is expected to move into northwest Minnesota Friday evening. Northerly winds behind a strong low pressure system will pull smoke south across the northern half of Minnesota through Monday morning. Smoke will produce air quality in Orange (Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups) category intermittently from Friday evening through noon on Monday.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 16 at 3:34PM CDT by NWS North Platte NE
entry.summary:
The following is transmitted in collaboration with the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services and the Nebraska Department of Environment and Energy...
WHAT...Air Quality Alert
WHERE...Northern Nebraska and portions of central Nebraska
WHEN...8/16/2024 5PM to 8/18/2024 3AM
POLLUTANT...PM 2.5 particulates
AIR QUALITY INDEX...Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups to Unhealthy
ADDITIONAL DETAILS...An alert for possible, periodic exposure to Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups (Air Quality Index orange category) to Unhealthy (Air Quality Index red category) air quality due to smoke has been issued for the following Nebraska counties - Sioux, Dawes, Box Butte, Sheridan, Garden, Cherry, Grant, Arthur, Keith, Hooker, McPherson, Lincoln, Thomas, Logan, Keya Paha, Brown, Rock, Blaine, Loup, Custer, Boyd, Holt, Garfield, Wheeler, Knox, Antelope, Boone, Cedar, Pierce, Madison, Dixon, Dakota, Wayne, Stanton, Thurston, Cuming, Burt, Dodge, and Washington from Friday, August 16 th , at 5 PM to Sunday, August 18 th , at 3 AM.
During Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups (AQI orange category) conditions, members of sensitive groups may experience health effects. Sensitive groups include people with heart or lung disease, older adults, and children. When conditions rise to the orange category, sensitive groups are advised to reduce prolonged or heavy exertion and avoid intense outdoor activities.
During Unhealthy AQI (Red category) conditions, some members of the general public may experience health effects and members of sensitive groups may experience more serious health effects. Sensitive groups include people with heart or lung disease, older adults, and children. When conditions rise to the red category, everyone is advised to avoid prolonged or heavy exertion and those in sensitive groups should consider moving activities indoors or rescheduling.
Smoke from Canadian and western U.S. wildfires may affect the air quality in Nebraska. Smoke levels and wind directions are monitored by Nebraska and other states to predict when impacts to the air quality may occur.
Information regarding wildfires and Impacts in Nebraska is available from the Nebraska Department of Environment and Energy (NDEE) at http://dee.ne.gov/NDEQProg.nsf/OnWeb/AirSA-3
Alerts are based on data available from weather forecasts, smoke plume modeling, satellite imagery, and from air quality monitors located in Omaha, Bellevue, Blair, Lincoln, Beatrice, Grand Island, and Scottsbluff.
Advisories for smoke and air quality are issued for affected areas by the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) and Department of Environment and Energy (NDEE) and posted on agency webpages and social media sites. By notifying the media and local health departments, alerts help citizens protect their health by informing them of days where outdoor activities should be reduced or avoided to minimize exposure to smoke.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 16 at 12:16PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
Oregon Department of Environmental Quality has issued an Air Quality Advisory...in effect until noon PDT Monday.
This air quality advisory covers Lake and northern Klamath counties due to wildfires burning in the region. The DEQ also expects intermittent smoke in eastern Douglas and Jackson County through this period due to smoke from surrounding fires.
The wildfire smoke combined with forecast conditions will cause air quality levels to fluctuate and could be at unhealthy levels.
Smoke levels can change rapidly depending on the weather and planned burn operations. Smoke can irritate the eyes and lungs and worsen some medical conditions. People most at risk include infants and young children, people with heart or lung disease, older adults and pregnant people.
People can take the following precautions to protect their health:
- Follow local burn restrictions to prevent deteriorating air quality. - Avoid strenuous outdoor activity during periods of poor air quality. - People with heart or lung problems and young children are especially vulnerable. These people should stay indoors while smoke levels are high. - Use certified High Efficiency Particulate Air (HEPA) filters in indoor heating, ventilation, cooling and air purification systems. - Avoid using wood-burning stoves and other sources of indoor smoke if possible.
For additional information...please visit the web site at https://oregonsmoke.org
entry.cap:areaDesc: Klamath, OR; Lake, OR

A Smoke Air Quality Advisory has been issued. Wildfires burning in the region combined with forecasted conditions will cause air quality to reach unhealthy levels.
Pollutants in smoke can cause burning eyes...runny nose...aggravate heart and lung diseases...and aggravate other serious health problems. Limit outdoor activities and keep children indoors if it is smoky. Please follow medical advice if you have a heart or lung condition.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 15 at 3:08PM CDT by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency has issued an Air Quality Alert for fine particles pollution. The Air Quality Index (AQI) is expected to reach the Red or Unhealthy category.
* WHERE...Northwest Minnesota.
* WHEN...From 3 PM CDT Friday to 6 PM CDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Some members of the general public may experience health effects. Sensitive groups, such as people with lung disease (including asthma), heart disease, and children and older adults, may experience health effects.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heavy ground-level smoke is expected to move into northwest Minnesota on Friday afternoon. Northerly winds behind a strong low pressure system will pull smoke south across the Red River valley. Smoke will reach the border around 3 pm and arrive at the Fargo/Moorhead area around 6 pm Friday. Northerly winds will persist for several days and additional smoke is expected to move into northern Minnesota Saturday afternoon. The alert area may need to be expanded to account for additional areas that might be impacted by heavy smoke. Smoke will initially produce air quality in the Red (Unhealthy) AQI category Friday afternoon but levels may improve to the Orange (Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups) category on Saturday. Smoke will linger until at least Sunday, as light northerly winds are expected to continue until Monday.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 15 at 12:29PM EDT until August 20 at 11:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding from the Intracoastal Waterway
* WHERE...A portion of northeast South Carolina, including the following county, Horry.
* WHEN...Until 1100 AM EDT Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...At 17 feet...flooding of about three dozen ground level structures on Rosewood Drive, Star Creek Circle, and Recreation Road worsens and about 24 more ground level structures begin to flood. Flooding expands on Rosewood Drive, River Road, Ed Smith Avenue, Creekside Drive, Mill Creek Road, Smith Boulevard, Folly Lane, John Henry Lane, Star Creek Circle, West Oak Circle and Roberta Lane with residences isolated. Zeddie Lane, Renata Lane, and Earls Road begin to flood. Lowest yards along Shem Creek Circle begin to flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1226 PM EDT, The Waterway at Socastee was at about 15.2 feet and is forecast to rise to a peak as high as 17 feet Monday into Tuesday. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Socastee. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
